title: Orthographic standards and the new media – if you can't beat them, join them
segmentation: Good morning, nice to see you all and thank you very much for inviting me to talk about this topic.
The outline of my.
Talk here is about the Danish language Council.
I think I need to tell you a little bit more about what we're doing.
About how we have done.
Also graphic standardization since 1736.
What happens to Danish in the new media and how we monitor the development of the language in various ways and I'll give a few suggestions for how to maybe make new standards for standardization.
And finally I will talk a little bit about how we spread the word around about the standards of the Danish language.
So.
The Danish Language Council was founded in 1955 and there was an orthography reform in 1948 and I'll come back to that and that led to the creation of the Council.
There is a law.
It's institutionalizing our work and also a legal notice by the ministry.
That sort of defines how our work is going to be undertaken.
We are part of the Ministry of Culture.
And our tasks are not only to answer questions, but to monitor the development of the Danish language.
So we are a research institution.
We provide the autographic standards for schools and public institutions.
They have to follow it by law and we give advice on language use in private and public institutions.
But we are also part of a greater system, namely the Corporation of the Nordic countries.
As you may know, Norwegian, Swedish and Danish R. Mutually intelligible.

Some say their dialects of each other, but as you know, dialect languages are dialects with an army and fleet, and both Norway and Sweden and Denmark have armies and fleets, and so we are languages, but we are mutually intelligible.
But of course, languages tend to drift away from each other, and some of our task is also to work for a better coordination between the Nordic languages.
So there's this mutual understandability.
Will continue.
When we monitor the development of Danish, what we do is we collect examples of new words and new usages and I will tell a little bit more about how we do that.
We track changes in orthography, morphology, syntax and semantics, and we have a lot of research projects, and we do contrastive studies with other languages.
When we do, when we give advice and information about the language it is.
It is mainly by answering questions from the public and we also publish a lot in various places, not only books but also websites and other things.
And we have a presence in newspapers and radio and TV and of course we cooperate with terminologist, lexicographers and others in various areas, so these are sort of the main activities.
If you look at the political side.

We are sort of a part of the Nordic language policy and the Danish Language Council also subscribes to these policies, standards and one of the main problems that we have is that the English language is taken over in many domains.
For instance at universities in many areas, and natural signs, for instance, teaching is almost exclusively done in English, especially at the Masters level.
PhD level is completely in English and at the BA level it's.

Partly English, partly Danish, but the Nordic language policy says that Nordic languages as well as English should be used as languages of signs, so they adopt the parallel strategies between the English language and the Nordic languages, and so for instant publishing, scientific results should be as highly regarded in the Nordic languages as in English, which is not the case at the moment.
So if you publish in an International Journal, you get more points when you publish in English.
Because the international journals are in English.
If you're publishing a National Journal, you get fewer points, and universities are paid according to the points that they earn from their scientists.
Maybe you have the same system and the system of course supports that.
You publish in English and not in your own language.
The same goes for scientific terminology and language.

For special purposes, they should be taught both in English and in one of the Nordic countries along languages, and this is not always the case and scientific terminology is a great problem because there is no systematic work for, at least in Denmark.
It is better in the other Nordic countries.
Um?
We want universities to have strategies for the choice of languages.

And for language parallelism and so on, it's not that we're against English, it's not that we don't think that they should use English, and that English is would not be a major means of communication.
I mean I, I'm standing up here talking English to you, but.
You need to take care of your own language in parallel, and that is the main point.
And so this is some of some of the actual problems that we had, and that is.
This is why there is a need for some kind of policy and the Nordic countries are pursuing these policies, and they're trying to encourage people to keep using their own language.
If you look at the structure of the Language Council, it is like this you have here a language Council consisting of an Institute which I'm the director of and we are something like 30 people.
There is a board of Representative of 4043 people who are elected or selected from major institutions in Denmark that have somehow an influence on language.

So these are representatives from the Ministry of Justice, the ministry, this Ministry of State, the Parliament, Journalists Unions, actors, unions, writers, unions, all kinds of groups, universities.
Who are working with languages and so on.

So people are coming from everywhere in society to become a member of the Board of Representatives and they select a board that has direct works directly with me and they also make smaller task forces that work with themes like orthography, publication, language policy and so on.
So we are not alone.
As an Institute we don't have, we cannot make our own decisions, but we are.

Sort of bound up with a lot of other people who are having influence on what we do, and on the top of everything the Minister of Culture has the final word and of course we have partners and users that also have an influence on our work.
If you look at orthographic standards, you may ask the question why standardized what is it good for?
Why should you have it?
And I mean there are lots of countries that don't have a codified standard.

They don't have a law that says this is the way you spell things and so on, but still they have then a defacto standard such As for instance, in English you would have the Oxford English Dictionary as a sort of defacto standard.
And well, in Denmark at least, the discussion has been why do we need them?
We want to facilitate reading, writing, teaching, especially and of course communication.
And this probably becomes more and more important than the new technologies that, for instance, communication and information retrieval in electronic media are easier if you have a sort of standard.
Instead of having 14 different spellings, variations of the same words, and of course in.
The course of history.
Orthographic standards have been used to support the national language to bring up the national language, especially in the 19th century.
That was a big issue.
But in Denmark, the first official act on the initial saw graffiti was already issued in 1717 hundred, 39 by Christian the 6th.
And it just said that students should be taught or school children should be taught a proper language and what they did.
They didn't have a dictionary or anything.
They took one book out and they said this one is the standard, so you should spell things the way it is written in this book.
And this was a book on great men and women in Denmark and sort of historical book.
And then in 1872, the first sort of dictionary guidebook to Danish came, which was the first official spelling dictionary.
And there were a few after that, and in 1955 the 1st that was the 4th Official Spelling Dictionary when we started our work.

And the reason that there was a big reform at that time, I will tell you a little bit later what changes were made through the different periods, but you can see there have been like 3 editions of this 1986, which is the 5th Spelling Dictionary.
And now we're just under about to release this 6th dictionary in November 2012.
So we are really busy at the moment finishing the book.
It is a book at the moment.
It's a book.
It's on CD and on the Internet it has about 3064 thousand words and at almost full coverage.
I mean you never have a full coverage, but common simplex words on the standard variety of Danish.
You have compounds who are not sort of actually derivable from the meaning of the components, and you have common abbreviation and autographical guidelines.
That's sort of the content of the book.
And then the new book.
There will be a revision of the vocabulary.
Of course.
I mean it's 10 years since the last revision was made and also the autographic guidelines will be changed.
There will be extended information about word meaning.
It's not just the list, there will be full information about inflection and some information about the word division, but no radical changes in the spelling except for a few things.
So the difference between the two you can see here in 2001 the word attack the Danish word for attack at IKEA.
It would be spelled like that and it would say it's the word and the ending in the preterite is PDE.

Well, if you would like to make an automatic generation of the preterite form, this would be very difficult because of course if you just put the ending PDE on the verb, you get 2 E's next to each other and as you see down here, this is the correct form.
So this form of the dictionary was not really very useful.
For instance, for computational applications was good for people, it was not very informative.
It only said the pressure, right?
So there's nothing about the present.
Nothing about the perfect as you can see them here.
So the new one has more information.
It has the R for the present.
It has the DE for the Fed right?
And it has the T for the perfect and it also has short very short description of what this word means to attack.
Because it is a foreign word and there is another word for attack.
So there is a tendency to make the dictionaries more informative, specially also because children seem to have great problems.
Sort of accepting the very compact notation of the dictionary as it has been made usually and which is a very normal lexicography lexicographical tradition.
Of course, the reason why things were so compact was because you had the printed dictionary in mind.
And of course you would try to bring everything together as much as possible in order to fill as many words as possible into the dictionary.
This is not so important anymore because the dictionary will mostly be used on the Internet, probably in the future, so there is much more space to have more information.
Sometimes the Danes thinks that certain 660-4000 words are too little.
I mean they say oh, doesn't the Danish language have more words and some same time stains things?
Oh, it's not in the Dictionary of Orthography, so we can't use it.
And of course that's ridiculous, but sometimes these miss appear and that is not such an easy way to go against that.
Of course there are lots of other dictionaries that cover much more.
The principles for orthography that we use when we do the dictionary.
I laid down in the legal notice that I told you about and there are two principles.
Once is, one is the tradition principle and the other one is the usage principle and basically they would go against each other.
So they're sort of contradictive principles, which is a bit weird.
And of course there are other important principles, such as the phonetic principle, which is common to everyone who does some kind of writing system and the principle of sign Constantine.

If you look at the partition suggestion principle, it says that words and what forms are written in accordance with the practice laid down in the legal notice on orthography from 1989 eighteen 92 and expressed in our dictionary since 1955.

So it means that the spelling is fixed except for the changes that follow from the other principle, the usage principle, and so the word should just be spelled the way they have always been to be steppin spelled.
That should sort of the basic tradition principle.

If you have loanwords and they've become common, then you would sort of write them in accordance with the original Danish words, mainly Latin and Greek and French words, whereas English words and newer foreign words they would not be domestic sized as much they would be written as in the language of origin.
And so the user's principal says that word forms are written in the accordance with practice, followed in the written users of competent language users.
So that is completely the opposite.
So you would say if language users start to spell things differently, then the users principal would force us to change.
It's the spelling of the word, so you can see those two principles go against each other.
So and how do you determine who is a competent language user?
I mean, who are these people anyway that make our language change?
This way over orthography change?
And of course, it's difficult to determine.
What we do of course to sort of support our decisions, is to use corpora, various texts collections and of course the Internet and corpus collections that we've made via various initiatives.
But still in these corporate you find text from language users and you have to prioritize.
Normally you would say competent language users are people who professionally deal with language that might be journalists.
That might be teachers that might be translators and others who have some sort of language conscious education that they use in their daily work.
So that's sort of the broad definition.
But in Denmark people would say oh, journalists they can't spell.
Or they would say oh teachers, they don't know the first thing about language, so so there's a very big discussion of who these competent language users are.
And I'll come back to this, but still this is the way.
The lowest formulated then of course we have the phonetic principle that says that we should have one letter corresponding to one phoneme or sound.
And there is a problem for Danish as you might have heard, because it is quite deep in this respect.
It's a bit like English.
Actually there are many sounds where you would say you can't really determine how to pronounce them, and I have some examples here.
For instance, in a normal very distinct pronunciation would say Crowe.
And here you would say Kava.
But in normal daily days.
The pronunciation would say cow and cow.
We would not be able to hear the different and the same here.
No, it no and no either.
I I'm very distinct, but in the normal Danish pronunciation between Noah, Noah, Noah would be just the same.

Then we have a principle of sign constancy, which goes against the phonetic principle, and it says that you have sort of signs written in the same way irrespective of that the surroundings might influence the pronunciation.
So you have the word flag which they said slay in danger.
But when you bring it together with flagpole, then it's flower Stan.
It's no longer fly stand but Flowers down.
So you get a diphthong here and the same, but on the other hand you also have.
Certain irregular ones, like men and men as you have it in English where you have a wild shift, so we tend to keep the sign constant.
Although there is a change in pronunciation of course to make it more transparent that the words are related.
So what does happen swell these years in Danish language?
Especially, there has been a lot of change from in Deftones from Y to I so fire becomes fire with an E and then 100 years later the eye becomes a J.
So fire comes gets a, J&R gets Jane and then again I to J love Kelly.
His love for instance fire means to broom.
You start.
You do all this work you know and then you change the I to J.
There you start to abolish long walls, which is typical in many languages.
I think that you get only one vowel whole and why, and you have over there.
And you going through all this trouble of changing the I2A J and then when you get to 1899 you drop it completely so you throw them out so they really been busy.
You can see that in 8089 they sort of adapt the foreign words more, you just throw out the agent theater and you write Karen Teen in a different way and in a 1980 you get official, rules.
And of course they start introducing two types of, rules so that people can fight about it.
So you have a grammatical, in the post, The post, is much like the English one.
They grow medic.
Medical One is much like the German one.
And in 1948, really things happening.
Sort of drastical things happen.
These are not really drastical thing, these are just, you know ordinary small changes.
But here after the Second World War Danes were, as you may know, occupied by the German forces.
And there was a big need of really noticing or making clear that Beins were Danes and they were belonging to the Nordic countries and they were not in any way related to Germany.
So they got rid of all the capital letters for nouns.
That was very important, and they introduced a new letter, this one.
Instead of AA's.
This was a Swedish one, so those two really drastical changes were made and they were made mainly for political reasons.
They were these things had been discussed for 100 years or something, but the war sort of made it possible to make to bring them to reality and really to bring them into the standards.
But people have been fighting about this for ages.
I mean, still in the 60s there were Danish writers sort of refusing to use.
This letter and and even today you can meet Danish writers saying I never start a sentence with a capital O, which is the sound of this letter.
O because it's so ugly, so so it's still a matter of discussion and still I&J are somehow an interesting part of the initial orthography.
So in 86 we got rid of some more eyes and turn them into JS, but we still have them like an oil and family and computer.
There is not a J but in line and vanilla it is different and there was some more to try adaptations of foreign words like mayonnaise, the French spelling.
Everybody got it wrong anyway, so we said OK, we give you a Danish alternative which is spelled like this, my unisa.
And the new thing that was happening was.
Alternatives were introduced, so it wasn't that we had only one standard.
We actually introduced several standards or alternative standards, so you were free to use either of these.
They were both equally correct, and of course it would be exciting to see what people would do with them when they had the possibility of using them.
But who that makes all these decisions?
That's really interesting, I think because it's not that we are doing this.
There is really a system for this.
This is the dictionary, it's green, and this is the third edition and.
If you have small changes like in linear and Vanillaware, just have the eye to the J for a couple of words.
This would be something that the editors could do on their own.
They would have to check with a task force that is.
Set down by the representatives and with the board and the representative.
But this could be sort of kept within the Danish Language Council.

We should not interfere with anybody else, but if there would be principle changes, such As for instance, introducing a new letter or change for the whole group of words, then there would be it would be necessary to have the Minister of Education and the Minister of Culture to sort of sanction these changes.
What we have of changing standards, for instance, is things in our inflection, which I think is interesting.
Here you have the word interview and there is a definite form interview it, which means the interview.
And then there's the plural interviews in English and in 1996 we introduced ER as the plural of this, but if you look on Google you find 30 examples of this form.
So in 2001 we introduced the English inflection S, so more interviews.
And if you look on Google you see there are like 8910.
There's quite a difference.
When I did this test at least.
But of course this is not easy because this is a foreign element in the Danish inflection system.
We know there are no Danish words that have any S in their inflection system, and we have the the morphological definiteness.
So if you have the interviews, you put an ending here, and suddenly you start integrating it into a into a system.
Here you can see up here as our suggestion is not to have the S in the plural, but here you have in the definite plural.
But here you can see examples of.
Good and competent language users 'cause these are is the church.
This is the commune and this is the University of Southern Denmark and they all have examples of using the English S within the Danish inflection system.
So we see here that there is a foreign element getting in slowly into the Danish inflection system.
And also domestication is still happening.
And for instance in 1986 and in the 2001 edition you can only write gimnazium.
You know the word, probably aquarium territory in old Latin words or Greek words that come into into the language and have been there for ages.
And now we are introducing in the new dictionary the sort of domestic sized form gymnasium fire into a toy, and these have actually been approved by the Minister now so that we can introduce them.
The interesting thing is we already did introduce them in 1986.
We wanted to introduce them, and at that time the Minister said no.
He was a very sort of classical educated man and he said no, we have these old forms.
They should not be changed and so he did.
We didn't get them into this dictionary so so much power for the Minister of Education but this time.
Funny enough, he was also the minister.
Now when we made the last change and I introduced this to him again.
And we talked about it and I showed him a lot of examples of actual use of these forms and all the examples I had were actually from the Ministry of Education of their website.
So he took a big jump in his chair, and then he accepted the changes.
So just to tell you how we talk about norms in Denmark, this is the way it is done.
So now you can use both forms in the future.
What happened to the word mayonnaise is also an interesting story.
This is the wrong spelling.
This is the Danish spelling.
And this is the French one, so we can see very clearly that Danes did not like the Danish version of the word mayonnaise.
In fact, it has been used a little bit in the beginning, but then you can see the French form took off and there was a big discussion about using this Danish word when it was first introduced.
People were furious.
They really thought it was barbaric to write it in a Danish way and everybody, I mean, most of the articles here.
On the word mayonnaise actually are about how ugly it is to write it in this way.

So.
The Danish Language Council was founded in 1955 and there was an orthography reform in 1948 and I'll come back to that and that led to the creation of the Council.
There is a law.
It's institutionalizing our work and also a legal notice by the ministry.
That sort of defines how our work is going to be undertaken.
We are part of the Ministry of Culture.
And our tasks are not only to answer questions, but to monitor the development of the Danish language.
So we are a research institution.
We provide the autographic standards for schools and public institutions.
They have to follow it by law and we give advice on language use in private and public institutions.
But we are also part of a greater system, namely the Corporation of the Nordic countries.
As you may know, Norwegian, Swedish and Danish R. Mutually intelligible.

Some say their dialects of each other, but as you know, dialect languages are dialects with an army and fleet, and both Norway and Sweden and Denmark have armies and fleets, and so we are languages, but we are mutually intelligible.
But of course, languages tend to drift away from each other, and some of our task is also to work for a better coordination between the Nordic languages.
So there's this mutual understandability.
Will continue.
When we monitor the development of Danish, what we do is we collect examples of new words and new usages and I will tell a little bit more about how we do that.
We track changes in orthography, morphology, syntax and semantics, and we have a lot of research projects, and we do contrastive studies with other languages.
When we do, when we give advice and information about the language it is.
It is mainly by answering questions from the public and we also publish a lot in various places, not only books but also websites and other things.
And we have a presence in newspapers and radio and TV and of course we cooperate with terminologist, lexicographers and others in various areas, so these are sort of the main activities.
If you look at the political side.

We are sort of a part of the Nordic language policy and the Danish Language Council also subscribes to these policies, standards and one of the main problems that we have is that the English language is taken over in many domains.
For instance at universities in many areas, and natural signs, for instance, teaching is almost exclusively done in English, especially at the Masters level.
PhD level is completely in English and at the BA level it's.

Partly English, partly Danish, but the Nordic language policy says that Nordic languages as well as English should be used as languages of signs, so they adopt the parallel strategies between the English language and the Nordic languages, and so for instant publishing, scientific results should be as highly regarded in the Nordic languages as in English, which is not the case at the moment.
So if you publish in an International Journal, you get more points when you publish in English.
Because the international journals are in English.
If you're publishing a National Journal, you get fewer points, and universities are paid according to the points that they earn from their scientists.
Maybe you have the same system and the system of course supports that.
You publish in English and not in your own language.
The same goes for scientific terminology and language.

It is better in the other Nordic countries.

We want universities to have strategies for the choice of languages.

I mean I, I'm standing up here talking English to you, but.
You need to take care of your own language in parallel, and that is the main point.
And so this is some of some of the actual problems that we had, and that is.
This is why there is a need for some kind of policy and the Nordic countries are pursuing these policies, and they're trying to encourage people to keep using their own language.
If you look at the structure of the Language Council, it is like this you have here a language Council consisting of an Institute which I'm the director of and we are something like 30 people.
There is a board of Representative of 4043 people who are elected or selected from major institutions in Denmark that have somehow an influence on language.

So these are representatives from the Ministry of Justice, the ministry, this Ministry of State, the Parliament, Journalists Unions, actors, unions, writers, unions, all kinds of groups, universities.
Who are working with languages and so on.

Why should you have it?

And well, in Denmark at least, the discussion has been why do we need them?
